comments.body:
IMO there is not much difference among the names "client", "cs" and "clientset" - they're usually used interchangeably. As this file is deprecated, so I leave the name as is. In other places that jointly used clientset and dynamic clientset, I renamed them to `client` and `dynamicClient`.

So I'm going to:
/hold cancel
This should be replaced with `config.PodInformer` to fetch pods.

comments.body:
It seems we rely on `testConfig.clientset`, so we can:

- put `factory.Config` in `testConfig`
- Or, put both `podInformer` and `clientset` in `testConfig` if we plan to eliminate `factory.Config` in the future

comments.body: Well, not this - the List in line 217 can.

And actually this is wrong. I consciously made it return early. Last scheduling is not representative, as in the last second of the test it'll schedule whatever number of Pods are left, which is not an interesting metric.

this also adds in a map,  useful for debugging on different situations i.e. on VMs where there may be lots of zeros...   total length of the map is relatively small since it aggregates, like 10 keys or so.

		qpsStats[qps] += 1
		if int32(qps) < minQps {
			minQps = int32(qps)

comments.body: I'd print qps stat at the end of the test, not in every iteration.
the nice thing about the qps every iteration is that you can "see" a test fail.

comments.body: I don't understand, but I also don't care enough:) It seems that it's some problem with a test setup, but if this makes results stable I'm completely fine with that.
agree, its a very weird issue.

So here is my take on some of this... I think the algorithm for evaluation here is flawed.   I think we should bin, throw out the high and low and take the average, as lumps should be expected.  This jiggery is far to brittle for my liking.  Standard pattern should be to normalize the curves and eliminate the outliers to determine base level drift on the average distribution.
Please add comment what is numGroups.
